awd_titl_txt: Ultracompact sample-to-answer nucleic acid test on USB stick
awd_abstract_narration:
Increased malaria control efforts have resulted in a dramatic reduction in the global malaria incidence over the past decade, and the World Health Organization has endorsed the ambitious goal of achieving worldwide malaria elimination and eradication. A change in focus from malaria control to malaria elimination requires easy and efficient ways to rapidly screen for malaria. Current malaria screening tests rely almost exclusively on microscopy and immunological tests. Both methods could miss significant information due to their limited detection abilities. Nucleic acid testing (NAT) is currently the most sensitive method available. Unfortunately, NAT-based methods developed to date mostly require certain infrastructures and skilled technicians. There is a critical need for an improved malaria screening test that combines the benefits of lateral flow-based testing (scalable throughput, minimal training) and the NATs (highly sensitive and specific). The success of the proposed research would enhance the health care system domestically and globally. As a platform technology, it would allow for delivering the highly sensitive test to remote, underserved and resource-limited communities. In addition, the proposed educational and outreach activity would foster student engagement through unique hands-on-experience-based interactive activities. 

The research objective of this proposal is to take a multidisciplinary approach to explore a highly sensitive and scalable malaria nucleic acid screening test on a USB interfaced device. This research objective will be achieved by carrying out the following three research tasks. Task 1, assay optimization and validation, with the goal to increase the DNA extraction yield and to increase the loop-mediated isothermal amplification assay copy number sensitivity. Task 2, device integration and instrumentation, with the goal to develop the disposable microfluidic chip and the ultracompact USB interfaced analyzer. Task 3, device performance evaluation with lab-archived blood samples collected from field sites, with the goal to determine its sensitivity, specificity, reproducibility and limits of detection. The innovation of the proposed work are three folds: (1) Highly sensitive malaria isothermal amplification assay could be performed as simple as lateral flow-based testing, (2) Scalable nucleic acid testing throughput and asynchronous processing capability provided by the cascading capability of a tier tree topology of USB hubs, and (3) Versatile platform technology that can be widely disseminated to situations that demand portability, connectivity and ease-of-use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Increased malaria control efforts have significantly reduced global malaria incidence. In support of this, the World Health Organization (WHO) has set an ambitious goal to eliminate and ultimately eradicate malaria worldwide. Achieving malaria elimination, however, requires shifting the focus from control to complete eradication, which involves identifying and treating both symptomatic and asymptomatic carriers to interrupt transmission. The success of these strategies depends heavily on highly sensitive malaria screening tests. Currently, most tests rely on microscopy and rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs), which, while effective in detecting acute symptomatic cases, often miss asymptomatic carriers in low-transmission areas due to a detection limit of about 50 parasites per microliter (µL). Nucleic acid testing (NAT) is the most sensitive method available, but most NAT-based techniques require advanced infrastructure and skilled personnel. Although there have been efforts to develop point-of-care NATs, existing devices struggle with limited sample processing and lack scalability for widespread use. There is a critical need for a malaria screening test that combines the benefits of both RDTs (which offer high throughput and ease of use) and NATs (which offer sensitivity and specificity).

During the course of this project, we successfully developed and validated a highly sensitive, ultracompact, and easy-to-use device with integrated "sample-in, answer-out" functionality for malaria screening. First, we conducted several rounds of assay optimization and validation. The overall analytical sensitivity of the LAMP assay depends on several factors, including the blood sample volume, parasite DNA extraction yield, the abundance of the target gene, and the copy number sensitivity of the LAMP assay. We explored strategies to enhance LAMP sensitivity by improving each of these elements. As a result, we achieved a sensitivity of 0.5 parasites/µL through two key tasks: (1) optimizing and increasing DNA extraction yield via integrated sample preparation and (2) refining LAMP primer sets to boost copy number sensitivity. Second, we developed a compact, portable device for point-of-care use, which includes a disposable microfluidic chip and an ultracompact analyzer. Third, we thoroughly tested the device under laboratory conditions to evaluate its sensitivity, specificity, reproducibility, and detection limits for asexual parasites. These efforts have laid the groundwork for its final adoption as a field-based point-of-care testing solution.

The completion of this project enables the potential delivery of accurate nucleic acid testing to remote, underserved, and resource-limited communities. Over the course of the project, four Ph.D. students, two Master's students, and five undergraduate students received support for technical training and professional skill development. They contributed to peer-reviewed journal publications and presented their research at conferences. Additionally, the outcomes of this research have been patented for technology transfer and incorporated into a summer camp, as well as the PI's course Micro & Nano Medical Devices, which benefited both undergraduate and graduate students. The project also led to creating a YouTube channel and actively involved underrepresented undergraduate students in research activities.
